Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the photo shows an alignment of Mercury, Venus, and Saturn over the Giza pyramids, which experts have deemed impossible.
Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the rarity of the alignment, stating that it occurred for the first time in 2,737 years, while other variants of the claim suggest it happens every 2,373 years.
Falters at times: The claim falters by presenting an image that is not reflective of the real world and does not align with the actual positions of the planets on the given date.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as the image was created using a free online program and does not correspond to the actual alignment of the planets.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the photo accurately depicts the alignment of the planets over the Giza pyramids, which experts have deemed impossible.
Exist alternative explanation: The alternative explanation provided by experts is that the photo was taken at a time when the planets were not visible from Giza and does not match the actual alignment of the planets.
